Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Physiological Trade-offs in Ecoimmunology: Costs for Individuals and Populations
Award.AbstractNarration: The immune system is important for health and survival in all organisms, including humans. The proposed research seeks to answer the question, "What are the costs of immunity?" This is a central question in the field of ecological immunology. A simplifying assumption is often made that a greater or longer-lasting immune response is advantageous. However, the costs of a more robust immune response may negatively affect other energy intensive processes such as reproduction. Currently, much of immunology research focuses on specific, isolated cellular components of the immune system. Although this level of understanding is important, it is also critical to comprehend how an overall immune response can affect the condition of an individual, including other vital physiological systems. Furthermore, it is presently unclear how individual measures, such as immunity, affect population changes over time. Understanding the link between individuals and populations will allow us to monitor more effectively the health and viability of natural populations, many of which are susceptible to an ever-changing landscape and climate. To address these knowledge gaps the proposed work will test (1) the energetic costs of immunity; (2) the effects of the immune system on other key physiological processes, notably reproduction; and (3) the links between individual immunity and natural populations. Finally, embedded within the research program is a research-based training initiative for future educators, which will incorporate those educators into the proposed scientific research. By providing opportunities for future educators to ?do science,? this research will enhance the educational experiences and understanding of the scientific process for educators and for their students. The impacts of this educational program even in its initial stages will be broad, because there is an inherent multiplier effect. In sum, the proposed research and educational program has the capability to transform the principles underlying immunological research and to enhance the science education curriculum both for future instructors and for their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The immune system is important for health and survival in all organisms, including humans. However, we still do not have a good understanding of the true costs of immunity. Presently a greater or longer-lasting immune response is thought to be advantageous, a simplifying assumption. Yet, the costs of a more robust immune response may negatively affect other processes in the body, such as reproduction. Understanding the true costs of immunity is therefore paramount to how we interpret these sorts of data moving forward.

Over the course of this project to address these underlying gaps in knowledge, we produced significant outcomes for all of our specific aims. Along these lines, we found that lizards adjust their energy expenditure (i.e., metabolism) and immune response depending on the magnitude of the immune challenge, but not in the way expected based on previous work in endotherms. Specifically, small challenges caused animals to invest more resources in recovering quickly and as a result increase performance in other traits such as their sprint speed to evade predators. However, with larger immune challenges animals instead chose efficiency, reduced their overall energy metabolism, food intake and speed at which they evaded predators. This is an exciting outcome and one contrary to the main idea in the field that immune challenges always result in an increase in energy expenditure. Finally, because temperature is important for all animals, especially ectotherms, we investigated how temperature played into this result. We found that immune challenged lizards spent more time at warmer temperatures compared to lizards not given an immune challenge, and the plasma from these immune challenged lizards performed better at warmer temperatures, suggesting that animals can behaviorally modify their immune system. Thus, the general assumption that ‘bigger is always better’ is not the case, and instead animals adjust their response and strategy depending on magnitude of the challenge at hand. Moreover, some animals can even do this behaviorally by adjusting their body temperature.

We also investigated interactions of the immune system with other important systems, namely reproduction. To this end we tracked where females were investing labeled essential nutrients in their body. This approach demonstrated, for the first time, direct resource competition among the reproductive and immune systems. Investment varied depending on both resource availability and reproductive stage of the animal. We likewise found that females given a mimicked bacterial infection differentially elevated their energy expenditure (i.e., metabolism) and immune response depending on where they were in the reproductive process. This finding suggests that immune responses are modulating depending on other key systems in the body, and are not always “maximized”. We further experimentally investigated female egg quality as an extension of reproductive investment, and found that females with more robust immunity had eggs with higher levels of oxidative stress, which have the potential to cause damage to developing embryos. This might suggest a tradeoff between female immunity and egg viability, thus shedding light on previously unidentified costs of maintenance of the mom’s immune system.

Looking at these relationships across wild populations of lizards we found important patterns with both life-span and environmental disturbance. Comparing animals along a latitudinal gradient that corresponded with life span, we found that depending on climate, northern (longer-lived) populations were allocating more energy into their immune systems and survival and less into immediate reproduction, as would be predicted in longer-lived animals.

We also found significant differences in survival among populations of lizards across an urban landscape, with rural animals living significantly longer. Lifespan was related to physiological measures of immunity, antioxidants, and stress. Analysis of naturally occurring elements (carbon and nitrogen), demonstrated that nutrition and resources are also linked to variations in immunity and stress across these free-living populations. Taking this a few steps farther, we found important genomic variants of our immune and stress indices across the urban landscape. We also have found shifts in genetic make-up (i.e., allele frequency) of populations across the urban landscape, suggesting that local adaptation in response to urbanization may be driving changes in physiological traits including immunity that are linked to survival. Understanding the link between individuals and populations will allow us to monitor more effectively the health and viability of natural populations, many of which are susceptible to an ever-changing landscape and climate.

Finally, this project trained high school, undergraduate, to graduate students in research. We also investigated the utility of ‘learning by doing’ via the incorporation of authentic science research into the curriculum of future secondary science teachers, which provided valuable preliminary results. Engaging education majors in the research process provided them with invaluable instructive experiences that cannot be accomplished in the classroom, and thus they may be better prepared for science education after school and may better teach real science to kids at an earlier age.
